title.narrative: Project Ignite Mozambique: Global Partnership in the Field of SRHR

description.narrative: Population Services International (PSI) seeks to break down barriers to access and use of voluntary, modern contraception among girls and young women (age 15-24), with the aim of reducing unintended pregnancies, reducing unsafe abortions and preventing transmission of sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs is funding PSI to test two innovative models, and two theories of change, to tackle youth and adolescent sexual health issues (2016-2020). The market development approach implemented by PSI in the DRC (2016-2017), Cote d'Ivoire (since November 2017), Haiti and Mozambique consists in addressing market failures that prevent Sara from accessing the contraceptive products and services she wants and needs. Main approaches used include a thorough landscape analysis to understand how the market is failing Sara (production to use spectrum analysis). This helps ensure that the response is highly context-specific and that programs in each country are geared towards prioritized market players to address the failures identified. PSI also uses user-centered design inspired techniques to gather consumer insights and develop fast prototypes. The Ecosystem development approach, implemented by Triggerise in India and Kenya, consists in improving health the livelihood of micro-entrepreneurs who are incentivized to improve access to contraceptive products and services. Using a peer-to-peer approach that connects consumers to local small businesses, Triggerise gives them the power to both access and deliver aid on their own terms. Building on these relationships, Triggerise uses rewards-based platforms to motivate consumers to make positive choices?helping them to overcome individual barriers as they arise while adding value back into their economies. The project will deliver on 5 outcomes: 1: Increased informed demand for SRH services by girls and young women, 2: Increased access to a wide range of SRH products and services for girls and young women, 3: Improved enabling environment for youth and young women for improving their SRH rights, 4: Create wealth (via improved depth and reach of the ecosystems) and 5: Improve lives (via improved SRHR health outcomes).

activity-date.narrative: While the contract was expected to be signed by January 1, 2016, contract signature was delayed and the contract wasn't signed by both parties until April 11, 2016
While the contract was expected to be signed by January 1, 2016, contract signature was delayed and the contract wasn't signed by both parties until April 11, 2016

mailing-address.narrative: PSI Europe SPACES - Herengracht 124-128 1015BT Amsterdam The Netherlands

sector.narrative: SRHR - Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights

title.narrative: Annual couple years of protection (CYPs) generated from services provided to adolescent girls and young women (15-24)
Annual couple years of protection (CYPs) generated from services provided to adolescent girls and young women (15-24)

comment.narrative: The baseline established is extrapolated from May-December information of women under 24 that received a family planning method. Total 2017 is the cumulative CYPs generated from services provided to AGYW < 24 years There is a decrease in the last quarter since December is a school vacation month.
The baseline established is extrapolated from May-December information of women under 24 that received a family planning method. 2017 annual targets are 32 736
Total 2017 is the cumulative CYPs generated from services provided to AGYW < 24 years old.

PSI Mozambique program is integrated. Our FP leverages efforts from different projects to help optimize resources and reach the highest number of beneficiaries. We work alongside Coalizão, a local youth organization that works with young people in and out of school. Community-based mobile brigades are organized in our 6 provinces to reach youth specifically. PSI TEM+ nurses provide health services at schools, while activistas provide information around HIV, STIs, among others. In the past quarter, we've seen a high number of youth that are willing to see a nurse when met in a location where they feel comfortable such as school. Nurses at our TEM+ facilities also see young people under 25. Condoms include pharmacy distribution channel, which is why objective was exceeded.

title.narrative: Number of AGYW continuing users of modern contraceptive method
Number of AGYW continuing users of modern contraceptive method

comment.narrative: During this reporting period 33,148 AGYW continuing users <24 years who received modern contraception.

title.narrative: Number of supported youth-friendly service delivery outlets that provide a minimum package of youth- friendly SRH services to young people, including short and long-acting reversible contraceptive methods

Number of supported youth-friendly service delivery outlets that provide a minimum package of youth- friendly SRH services to young people, including short and long-acting reversible contraceptive methods

comment.narrative: All 23 of PSI network clinics meet PSI minimum standards that have been set forth by PSI Global Clinical Standards and Guidelines and offer short and long acting reversible methods for youth. All providers at these sites have received YFHS training in the last 12 months.
During Q4 we have had 56 outlets providing YFS to young people. From this 40, there were Tem+ clinics and 16 schools.
In Q2 2018, there were 102 outlets providing youth-friendly health services to young people (42 Tem+ clinics and 60 schools).
In Q3 we have 36 Tem+ clinics and 50 schools with YFS

title.narrative: Number of youth (15-24) in school & out of school reached with information on sexuality, HIV, STIs, pregnancy, contraceptives
Number of youth (15-24) in school & out of school reached with information on sexuality, HIV, STIs, pregnancy, contraceptives

comment.narrative: In Q1 and Q2 a higher number of youth were reached due the ongoing activities of the MOBIZ program. In Q4 period 3 589 youth (15-24) were reached with messaging and referred to a school or given information on where to access both condoms and FP services both in and out of schools. From this, 2 675 were referred in a School and 914 out of School. A total of 139 189 have been reached in 2017.
In Q2, there is a recovery in the number of youth reached with information on SRH, because there were no major vacation period this quarter.

In this period 2,309 youth (15-24) were reached with messaging and referred to a school or given information on where to access both condoms and FP services both in and out of schools. The lower number is due to the extended vacation periods that happened this year due to the Census, and the end of the Mobiz project. A total of 135,600 have been reached to date (Q1, Q2 and Q3).

Our youth-based activities cover topics around family planning, SRH, relationships and those are often led by peer educators and community health workers who then refer young people to nurses. TEM+ nurses offer counseling at TEM+ facilities, schools, or in community-led activities allowing to reach youth in & out of school.

title.narrative: Number of changes in policies, laws, legal guidelines leading to decrease of legal barriers for AGYW in their sexual and reproductive health and rights
Number of changes in policies, laws, legal guidelines leading to decrease of legal barriers for AGYW in their sexual and reproductive health and rights

comment.narrative: In the last quarter of 2017 the "Boletim da Republica" on Safe Abortion was released, giving guidance on the SA activities and Protocols. The training of trainers was held in November 2017.
The DSR group prepared comments on the penal code, which legalized safe abortion without restrictions as to reason.

title.narrative: Number of new adolescent girls and young women adopters of modern contraceptive methods
Number of new adolescent girls and young women adopters of modern contraceptive methods

comment.narrative: This reporting period 23,618 AGYW adopters received modern contraception at TEM+ facilities, schools, and pharmacies.

We work alongside Coalizão, a local youth organization that works with young people in and out of school. Community-based mobile brigades are organized in our 6 provinces to reach youth specifically. In the past quarter, we've seen a high number of youth that are willing to see a nurse when met in a location where they feel comfortable such as school. Nurses at our TEM+ facilities also see young people under 25. Condoms include pharmacy distribution channel, which is why objective was exceeded.
